caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 45.
Caecum semilaeve
. A . Profile view with periostracum (SBMNH 452519). B . Profile view without periostracum (SBMNH 452519). C . Ventral view (SBMNH 452564). D . Syntype, NHMUK 1857.6.4.1526. E . Neotype, LACM 3758. F . Illustration of
C. elongatum var. semilaeve
from Brann (1966) . G . Operculum, exterior surface (SBMNH 452434). H . Operculum, interior surface (SBMNH 452434).

FIGURE 46.
Caecum semilaeve
shells at different growth stages. A . Protoconch and teleoconchs I to II (LACM 1971-83.57). B . teleoconchs I to III (LACM 1972-42.69). C . Teleoconchs III to IV (SBMNH 452564). D . Teleoconchs III to IV (SBMNH 452564). E . Surface of teleoconchs I to IV (SBMNH 452564). F . Surface of teleoconch V (LACM 1975-9.16). G . Surface of teleoconch VI (LACM 1972-52.68). H . Teleoconchs IV to V (SBMNH 132338). I . Teleoconchs V to VI, aberrant specimen (LACM 1975-9.16). J . Teleoconch V (LACM 1972-52.68). K . Teleoconch VI (SBMNH 452564).

subSubSection.paragraph:
Original diagnosis. “?
var. semilaeve
; t. huc et illuc annulata, huc et illuc laevi.” Carpenter (1857: 319) .

Distribution and Habitat. From Magdalena Bay, Baja California , Mexico to Tumbes , Peru , including the Gulf of California and the Galapagos Islands. Intertidal to
100 m .
Common on coarse sand and rubble substrates.

Remarks. Carpenter (1857) originally described
Caecum semilaeve
from a one adult specimen and a posterior fragment. Unfortunately, the adult specimen is lost and the fragment is in such poor condition it is not recognizable (NHMUK 1857.6.4.1526, Fig. 45D ). For taxonomic stability a neotype is herein designated for
C. semilaeve
(LACM 3758, Fig. 45E ).

Lightfoot (1993b: 82) mentioned and illustrated a species that she dubbed “
Brochina
species #6”. Her species is actually an early subadult of
Caecum semilaeve
. However, Lightfoot did not recognize it as such, because the varix at this stage is just a simple apertural swelling and quite different from that of the adult.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 47.
Caecum semilaeve
. A . Conceptual reconstruction of growth stages. B . Species distribution map.

subSubSection.paragraph:
While studying the subadult stages of
Caecum semilaeve
, two observations were made. First, it appears that only in the teleoconch V stage does the species occasionally develop axial ribs on the tube beyond two or three ( Fig. 46J ). Second,
C. semilaeve
seems to form more aberrant specimens ( Fig. 46I ) than any other eastern Pacific caecid observed to date.
